contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "someone" represents a king and his army. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: someone who will destroy nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "a voice" represents a messenger. Alternate translation: "a messenger comes and tells about what is happening in Dan" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: a voice is bringing news from Dan

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sword is a synecdoche for all of the different weapons that people use in war. Alternate translation: "They will use their weapons to conquer your strong cities that you trusted to protect you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: They will beat down with a sword your fortified cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "nation" represents the army of the nation. Alternate translation: "the army of a great nation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: a great nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "Jerusalem" here is a synecdoche for all the people of Judah. Alternate translation: "Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents Jeremiah, emphasizing his feelings and emotions. Alternate translation: "I feel sick deep down inside me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: my heart is sick

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people are represented by their "tongues" to emphasize their speech. Alternate translation: "They teach deceitful things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Their tongues teach deceitful things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh's speech is represented by his "mouth." Alternate translation: "Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the mouth of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah is speaking as if he were the whole tribe of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jeremiah represents the whole tribe of Israel. Alternate translation: "but we must bear it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: but I must bear it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jeremiah represents the whole tribe of Israel. Alternate translation: "Our enemies have taken our children away from us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: They have taken my children away from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the men refer to their "hand" to emphasize that they plan to kill him themselves. Alternate translation: "we ourselves will kill you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: you will die by our hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person is referred to by his "feet" to emphasize that he is walking. Alternate translation: "before he causes you to trip and fall as you walk" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: before he causes your feet to stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "gates," which keep enemies out of cities and where people conduct business and government, is a synecdoche for Judah's cities, and Judah's cities are a metonym for the people who live in them. Alternate translation: "let her cities fall apart" or "let the people in her cities become unable to defend themselves" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: let her gates fall apart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are referred to by their "feet" to emphasize their walking away from Yahweh. Alternate translation: "have not kept themselves" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: have not held back their feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "eye" represents Yahweh who sees all that they do. Alternate translation: "I am watching everything they do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: my eye is on all their ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "eyes" represents Yahweh who sees. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "They cannot conceal their iniquity from me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Their iniquity cannot be concealed from before my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sinful habits of the people are spoken of as if their sins had been engraved on their own hearts. The word "hearts" refers to the whole person: their thoughts, emotions, and actions. Alternate translation: "engraved in their very beings" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: engraved on the tablet of their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "lips" represents Jeremiah who spoke. The word "proclamations" can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: "the proclamations that I spoke" or "the things that I proclaimed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: the proclamations that came from my lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "feet" represents Jeremiah. Alternate translation: "have hidden traps for me" or "have hidden traps for me to step on" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: have hidden traps for my feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "eyes" represents Pashhur. Alternate translation: "you will see it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: your eyes will see it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words "heart" and "bones" represent Jeremiah's innermost being. Jeremiah speaks of being unable to not speak Yahweh's message as if Yahweh's message were a fire that burns within him. Alternate translation: "Yahweh's word is like a fire that burns deep within me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it is like a fire in my heart, held within my bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "days" represents all the days of Jeremiah's life. Alternate translation: "my life is filled with shame" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: my days are filled with shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "nations" refers to the people from those nations that pass by. Alternate translation: "Then many people from various nations will pass by this city" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Then many nations will pass by this city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hands" refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: "They strengthen those who do evil" or "They encourage people who do evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: They strengthen the hands of evildoers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The voice is a synecdoche for the person, and the same word can be translated "listen" or "obey." Alternate translation: "obey Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: listen to the voice of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The face is a synecdoche for the whole person. Alternate translation: "cause Yahweh to be less angry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: appease the face of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a synecdoche for the person. Alternate translation: "Have those kings' ambassadors, who ... Judah, take them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Send them by the hand of those kings' ambassadors who ... Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah gave the scroll to Elasah so that Elasah could take it to Babylon. The reader should understand that Elasah probably put the scroll in a container to keep it safe as he traveled. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: by the hand of Elasah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mouth" and "eyes" represent the whole person. Alternate translation: "Zedekiah himself will see and directly speak with Nebuchadnezzar" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: His mouth will speak to the king's mouth, and his eyes will see the king's eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is represented by his "face." This phrase shows Yahweh's displeasure with the city. Alternate translation: "I have turned away from you" or "I am no longer concerned with you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I hide my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a synecdoche for the person. Alternate translation: "he had Jeremiah the prophet proclaim" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: he proclaimed by the hand of Jeremiah the prophet

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes are a synecdoche for the whole person. The reader should also understand that others probably helped the king of Babylon kill Zedekiah's sons. Alternate translation: "forced Zedekiah to watch as the king's soldiers killed Zedekiah's sons" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: slaughtered Zedekiah's sons before his own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Ishmael" represents himself and the ten men with him. Alternate translation: "Then Ishmael and the ten men with him killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Then Ishmael killed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here King Baasha represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: "against Baasha, king of Israel, and his army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: against King Baasha of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Ishmael represents himself and all of his men. Alternate translation: "Ishmael and his men filled it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Ishmael son of Nethaniah filled it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Ishmael represents himself and his men. Alternate translation: "Ishmael and his men captured" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Ishmael captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Ishmael" represents himself and all of his men. Alternate translation: "Ishmael and his men" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Ishmael son of Nethaniah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Ishmael" represents himself and all of his men. Alternate translation: "Ishmael and his men ... found them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Ishmael son of Nethaniah ... found him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Ishmael" represents himself and all of his men. Alternate translation: "whom Ishmael and his men had captured" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: whom Ishmael had captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: "He" refers to Ishmael who represents himself and the eight men with him. Alternate translation: "They went to the people of Ammon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: He went to the people of Ammon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The men are used to refer to all the people because they are the leaders in their families. Alternate translation: "anyone who sets out" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])
contextId.glQuote: all the men who set out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem is referred to by the part of the city where people walk. This means the people did evil things in public places. Alternate translation: "Jerusalem" or "the public places of Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the streets of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "streets" represent the public places in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: "in the public places of Jerusalem" or "in Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the streets of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mouths" and "hands" represent the whole person. Alternate translation: "have done what you promised to do when you said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: have said with your mouths and carried out with your hands what you said

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents the whole person. The person's sad crying is compared to the sad music played on a flute at a funeral. Alternate translation: "I cry sadly for Moab. My cries are like the sad music a person plays on a flute at a funeral" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: my heart is lamenting for Moab like a flute

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the pit" and "the trap" represent all the different bad things that will happen to the people. People will run away to escape one bad thing but they will just experience another bad thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: fall into the pit ... caught in the trap

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "forehead" and "top of the heads" represent the people of Moab as a whole. Alternate translation: "It will burn up all the people in Moab who noisily boasted very much" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: It will devour the forehead of Moab and the top of the heads of the boastful people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a synecdoche for the person. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 37:2](../37/02.md). Alternate translation: "through Jeremiah, who was a prophet" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: by the hand of Jeremiah the prophet

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the time when the Medes and Persians conquered Babylon in 539 BC. Here "nation" represents their armies. Alternate translation: "the armies of a great nation and many kings" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: a great nation and many kings

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes are a synecdoche for the whole person. The reader should also understand that others probably helped the king of Babylon kill Zedekiah's sons. Alternate translation: "forced Zedekiah to watch as the king of Babylon slaughtered Zedekiah's sons" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: slaughtered Zedekiah's sons before his own eyes
